skill.name: enact/hello-rust
skill.description: A simple Rust greeting tool that compiles and runs a basic Rust program to greet users by name.
skill.summary: Simple Rust tool that compiles and runs a greeting program
skill.author: EnactProtocol

security_audit.summary: Static scanner flagged 3 patterns including external_commands and weak cryptographic algorithms. Evaluation reveals all findings are false positives. The external_commands pattern at SKILL.md:33 is a bash documentation example, not code execution. The weak crypto flags at lines 5 and 14 are YAML description fields, not cryptographic code. The skill is a simple greeting tool with no malicious intent.

medium_findings.title: External Commands Documentation Misidentified
medium_findings.description: Static scanner flagged 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' at SKILL.md:33. This is a false positive - the line contains a bash example in a code block: `enact run ./examples/hello-rust --input "name=Alice"`. This is documentation showing usage, not actual code execution.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: The flagged content is clearly a bash command example within a markdown code block, not Ruby code or backtick execution. No command injection risk exists in documentation.

medium_findings.title: YAML Description Fields Misidentified as Cryptographic Algorithms
medium_findings.description: Static scanner flagged 'Weak cryptographic algorithm' at SKILL.md:5 and 14. This is a false positive - both lines are simple YAML description fields: `description: "A simple Rust greeting tool"` and `description: "Name to greet"`. No cryptographic algorithms are present in this skill.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are standard YAML metadata fields containing plain text descriptions. No cryptographic functions, encryption, hashing, or related code exists in the skill files.

content.value_statement: Users who need simple compiled Rust executables can use this skill to build and run basic Rust programs that accept command-line arguments and produce greeting output.
actual_capabilities: Compiles Rust source code using rustc
Runs compiled Rust executables with command-line arguments
Produces greeting output with the provided name
Uses Enact protocol for skill execution
limitations: Only runs pre-defined Rust code in hello.rs
Cannot compile arbitrary Rust source files
No network or filesystem access beyond the defined build and run commands
Simple greeting output only, no complex logic or external dependencies

use_cases.title: Learn Rust basics
use_cases.description: New Rust developers can see how a simple Rust program reads command-line arguments and produces output.

use_cases.title: Build simple CLI tools
use_cases.description: Developers can use this as a template for creating basic Rust CLI tools that accept user input via arguments.

use_cases.title: Enact protocol demonstration
use_cases.description: Users exploring the Enact protocol can study this minimal example to understand skill definition structure.

prompt_templates.title: Basic greeting
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the enact/hello-rust skill to greet me.
prompt_templates.scenario: Simple invocation to get a default greeting

prompt_templates.title: Custom name greeting
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the enact/hello-rust skill to greet Alice.
prompt_templates.scenario: Providing a specific name as input

prompt_templates.title: Interactive conversation
prompt_templates.prompt: Greet me using the Rust greeting tool. My name is Bob.
prompt_templates.scenario: Natural language request for a greeting

prompt_templates.title: Multiple greetings
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to use the Rust greeting skill to greet multiple people one by one.
prompt_templates.scenario: Using the skill repeatedly with different inputs

best_practices: Use descriptive names when invoking the skill for personalized greetings
Review the SKILL.md to understand the input schema before use
Chain multiple skill calls together for more complex workflows
anti_patterns: Do not expect complex computation or external API calls
Avoid using this skill for production greeting services
Do not modify the source code through skill invocation

faq.question: What does this skill do?
faq.answer: This skill compiles and runs a simple Rust program that greets you by name. It takes a name input and outputs Hello, {name}! ðŸ¦€.

faq.question: Can I customize the greeting message?
faq.answer: No. The greeting message is hardcoded in the Rust source code. You can only change the name parameter.

faq.question: What input does this skill accept?
faq.answer: The skill accepts a 'name' parameter (string) with a default value of 'World' if not provided.

faq.question: Does this skill make network requests?
faq.answer: No. This skill only compiles and runs local Rust code with no network access.

faq.question: Can I use this with other skills?
faq.answer: Yes, you can chain this skill with other skills in a conversation. The output can be referenced in subsequent skill calls.

faq.question: What tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The skill definition follows the Enact protocol specification.
